degree_multipliers.rationale: Community organizers and campaign volunteers build very large social networks through their activism and outreach activities.
Full-time workers have regular workplace interactions that expand their social networks significantly.
Highly extraverted individuals naturally accumulate more social connections across all contexts.
Managers and professionals maintain broad networks for career advancement, client relationships, and professional associations.
Very frequent churchgoers are deeply embedded in congregational social networks and often take on leadership or volunteer roles.
Heavy social media users maintain more online connections and are exposed to and engage with more people digitally.
Union members participate in organized labor networks, meetings, and collective activities that expand social ties.

edge_type_rules.name: household_member
edge_type_rules.condition: a_household_income == b_household_income and a_state == b_state and a_urban_rural == b_urban_rural and a_marital_status == b_marital_status
edge_type_rules.description: People sharing the same household income, state, residential setting, and marital status are likely household members or domestic partners — a strong proxy for actual co-residence.

edge_type_rules.name: religious_community
edge_type_rules.condition: a_religious_affiliation == b_religious_affiliation and a_state == b_state and a_urban_rural == b_urban_rural
edge_type_rules.description: Members of the same religious congregation within the same state and community setting who attend services together.

edge_type_rules.name: political_community
edge_type_rules.description: People who share political affiliation in the same state, connected through local party activities, rallies, and civic engagement.

edge_type_rules.name: neighbor
edge_type_rules.condition: a_state == b_state and a_urban_rural == b_urban_rural and a_race_ethnicity == b_race_ethnicity
edge_type_rules.description: People in the same state, residential setting, and racial/ethnic community who are likely geographic neighbors or community members.

edge_type_rules.name: coworker
edge_type_rules.condition: a_occupation == b_occupation and a_state == b_state and a_employment_status == b_employment_status
edge_type_rules.description: People in the same occupation and employment status within the same state, likely sharing professional or workplace networks.

edge_type_rules.name: acquaintance
edge_type_rules.description: General acquaintances who live in the same state with some loose social connection.

influence_factors.description: Higher education is associated with greater perceived credibility and persuasiveness on policy issues; more educated people tend to shape opinions of less educated peers.

influence_factors.levels: {"Rarely/Never votes": 1, "Votes sometimes": 2, "Votes regularly": 3, "Actively volunteers or campaigns": 4}
influence_factors.description: Civically active individuals — especially organizers and campaigners — are opinion leaders who actively try to persuade others on political and social issues.
People with higher need for cognition process information more deeply and craft more coherent arguments, making them more persuasive in political discussions.
Individuals with higher institutional trust are seen as more mainstream and credible sources, giving them modest influence advantage in opinion dynamics.
